data.title: Here are 10 ways to celebrate the Kentucky Derby in the Milwaukee area, from parties to a river rubber duck race to shuffleboard
data.meta_description: The Kentucky Derby turns the big 150 this year. And, you better believe the celebrations will be reaching the Milwaukee area.
data.text:
The Kentucky Derby turns the big 150 this year. And, you better believe the celebrations will be reaching the Milwaukee area.

The big race is Saturday. Post time is at 5:57 p.m. CT.

So, don hats, bowties and bright colors — and get ready for what's often called "the most exciting two minutes in sports."

Here's what some local restaurants, bars, hotels and venues are doing this year, from Maxie's annual Derby Day party to The Bridgewater Modern Grill's inaugural Kentucky Derby celebration:

Maxie's: Benefits Hunger Task Force, Kentucky Derby-inspired menu, live music and contests

Maxie's annual Debry Day party is again doubling as a fundraiser for Hunger Task Force, according to a news release.

A Kentucky Derby-themed menu will be available Thursday through Saturday at the Milwaukee restaurant, 6732 W. Fairview Ave., and will feature Kentucky hot browns, fried bologna sandwiches and bourbon BBQ salmon.

On Saturday, doors open at 2 p.m. for food, drinks, pre-race coverage and an outdoorperformance by Jackson Park Jazz Orchestra, the release said.

There are three donation levels for entry into the event, which can be purchased at maxiesmke.com.

In-field ($20 donation per person before Derby Day or $25 in-person on the day of):

Limited table seating outside on first-come, first-served basis. These tables include outdoor service.

Food truck with Derby food, beer, wine and cocktails for people who don't get a table.

Outdoor bar.

One "betting" form.

Jackson Park Jazz Orchestra will be playing outside.

There will be multiple TVs to view the race on.

Note: The donation doesn't include food, beverage, tax or gratuity.

Grand Stand ($40 donation per person):

A reserved indoor table with a guaranteed view of televised race coverage. The tables — which seat two to eight people — are available between 2 and 3:30 p.m. and are reserved until the race is over.

Full service provided by Maxie's staff.

Two "betting" forms per person.

Note: The donation doesn't include food, beverage, tax or gratuity.

Clubhouse ($80 donation per person):

A buffet of Maxie's Derby menu food from 2:30 to 5:30 p.m.

A private cash bar away from the rest of the party.

Two "betting" forms per person.

A dedicated port-a-let for Clubhouse guests only.

The Clubhouse area is available until the race is over, at around 6 p.m.

Does not include beverages, or tax and gratuity on beverages.

During the party, there will also be a prize raffle, a 50/50 cash raffle and a race winner's raffle, as well as best dressed and hat contests. Maxie’s will continue regular indoor table service following the race until 9 p.m.

“To date, we’ve received more than $115,000 through Maxie’s to help ensure our neighbors in need can receive emergency food with dignity, on the day they need it and in the neighborhood they live in," Sherrie Tussler, CEO of Hunger Task Force, said in the release.

The Bridgewater Modern Grill to host its first Kentucky Derby celebration

The Bridgewater Modern Grill is hosting its first Kentucky Derby celebration, according to a news release.

There will be specialty food and drinks. Races will be played on the big screens.

Attendees are encouraged to "dress to impress" in their "finest derby day attire," the release said.

The party begins at 1 p.m. Saturday at 2011 S. 1st St., Milwaukee. Reservations are encouraged and can be made at bridgewatermke.com.

The Iron Horse Hotel's 'Talk Derby To Me' party

The Iron Horse Hotel is throwing its annual "Talk Derby To Me" party.

It'll be a "lavish" experience, featuring additional bars, vendors, food, mint julep drink packages, live entertainment, jumbo screens showing the race and VIP areas with table service, according to the hotel's website.

Guests are encouraged to dress in their "Derby finest" and compete in best hat and best bow tie contests.

While the event is free and open to the public, the website said, there are two VIP package options to "elevate" the experience:

Belmont VIP Package: Includes two-hour open bar, four courses of hors d’oeuvres and outdoor seating located in The Yard.

Preakness VIP Package: Includes two-hour open bar, four courses of hors d’oeuvres and indoor seating located in the lobby.

To reserve a private table, call 414-831-4615 or email talkderbytome@theironhorsehotel.com.

The event, at 500 W. Florida St., runs from 2 to 7 p.m. Saturday.

Matty's Bar & Grille: Jumbotron, food and drink specials, contests, tastings of the Derby's official bourbon and live music

At Matty's Bar & Grille's Kentucky Derby Party, the big race will be played on an 18-foot LED Jumbotron in the bar's Big Backyard, according to its Facebook event page.

Food and drink specials will be offered. And, attendees can taste the official bourbon of the Derby from the Woodford Reserve family from 1 to 3 p.m., the event page said.

Sport those Derby hats and attire. Prizes will be given out for the best dressed guy, gal, couple and hat. Nominations end at 4 p.m. and judging is at 5 p.m.

There will be live music from the Todd Bryant Trio from 1 to 5 p.m., and Borderline Reckless at 8 p.m.

The party at Matty's, 14460 College Ave., New Berlin, kicks off at 11 a.m.

Rebellion Brewing KenDucky Derby river rubber duck race fundraiser for All My Friends Inc.

While the Kentucky Derby is all about horses, a different animal stars in this local Derby Day event.

Rebellion Brewing is again hosting a KenDucky Derby river rubber duck race in Cedarburg as a fundraiser for the All My Friends Inc. organization, according to the event's Facebook page.

Day-of duck sales run from 11 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. while supplies last. It costs $5 per duck, five ducks for $20 or 20 ducks for $60, according to the event page. People can purchase ducks in advance by messaging the org on Facebook.

Burton Landscaping will use a skid loader to dump the ducks over the Columbia Road bridge into Cedar Creek to start the race at 4 p.m.

Monetary prizes will be from percentage of sales, the event page said. First place will win 10%, second place will receive 5% and third place will get 2.5%.

An additional 20 ducks will be plucked at random to win other prizes.

Participants don't need to be present to win, the page noted.

There will be ducky merch for sale, specialty cocktails and beer. The Graze Outdoors food truck will be arriving at 11:30 a.m.

At 2 p.m., the Cedarburg Police Department will be giving families tours of a squad car. Maverick from the Grafton Police Department will be meeting families from 2 to 4 p.m. and teaching them about the K-9 Unit.

Central Standard Crafthouse and Kitchen's Kentucky Bourby Party

Central Standard Crafthouse and Kitchen is hosting a Kentucky Bourby Party, according to its website.

There will be eight cocktails themed around "the rich flavors of bourbon," as well as Derby fare.

"Test your luck with horse betting, spin the prize wheel for exciting giveaways, and strut your stuff in our contest for the best derby outfit," the website said.

Tickets cost $15 each and include one Derby cocktail, snacks, betting, prizes and entrance into a contest for best hat/outfit. Tickets can be purchased at thecentralstandard.com/upcoming-events/#id=kentucky-bourby-party-milwaukee.

The party runs from 1:30 to 6:30 p.m. Saturday at 320 E. Clybourn St., Milwaukee.

Lush Popcorn hosting 'casual chic' Kentucky Derby party

Lush Popcorn is hosting "a casual chic" Kentucky Derby party, according to its Facebook event page.

Expect mint julep punch, southern cocktails and NA options, as well as Derby pie.

There will be a best dressed competition and music, too.

The party starts at 2 p.m. at 920 E. Locust St., Milwaukee. It's free to attend and open to the public, the page noted.

NorthSouth Club: Shuffleboard, mint juleps and chance to win bottle of Woodford Reserve Derby

Get your shuffleboard on while sipping a mint julep at NorthSouth Club's Kentucky Derby celebration.

Attendees can reserve 1½-hour time slots for shuffleboard for Saturday's event. A mint julep is included, according to a Facebook post from the bar. Reservations can be made here. It costs $20 per person and there can be up to four people per court.

There will also be a best dressed contest, as well as a giveaway contest with a chance to win a bottle of Woodford Reserve Derby, the post said.

The event runs from 11:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. at 230 E. Pittsburgh Ave., Milwaukee.

Saint Kate - The Arts Hotel: Large projector screen, special drinks, bites and contests

Milwaukee's Saint Kate - The Arts Hotel is hosting its annual "Run for the Roses" event in The Bar in partnership with Woodford Reserve, according to the hotel's website.

Festivities include a live viewing party on a large projector, and live bluegrass music from Frogwater.

There will be a special menu with select bites, and a featured drink menu that includes traditional mint julep cocktails. Each mint julep bought gets the purchaser a raffle ticket for various giveaways.

"Put on your fanciest hat or best bowtie," the website said. People can enter a contest for best dressed and best hat, with the winner taking home prizes from Saint Kate and Woodford Reserve.

The event, at 139 E. Kilbourn Ave., starts at 1 p.m. Saturday and is free.

Perspective Brewing Co.: Mint Julep Hard Seltzer on tap, gourmet grilled cheese food truck

Perspective Brewing Co. will be serving up its Mint Julep Hard Seltzer on tap all day long at its Kentucky Derby event, according to its Facebook event page.

"Wear those fancy hats and throw on your best fit," the post said.

The brewing company will have drink specials rolling on select beverages based on the races. Shorty's Gourmet Grilled Cheese Food Truck will be on-site from 3 to 7 p.m.

The races will be played with sound all day long.

The party at Perspective, 7508 W. Greenfield Ave., West Allis, runs from noon to 7 p.m.
